questions.text: Individuals with mild intellectual disability can typically learn academic skills up to what level?
questions.solution:
Developmental Characteristics of Intellectual Disability

Levels of Intellectual Disability:

  1. Profound Intellectual Disability:
    • Gross disability with minimal sensorimotor functioning.
    • Requires constant nursing care and supervision.
    • Limited motor and speech development; very minimal self-care ability.
  2. Severe Intellectual Disability:
    • Poor motor development; minimal speech and communication skills.
    • Limited ability to benefit from self-help training.
    • May develop basic health habits with systematic training.
    • Requires complete supervision for self-maintenance.
  3. Moderate Intellectual Disability:
    • Can learn to communicate; poor social awareness.
    • Benefits from training in social and occupational skills.
    • May achieve self-maintenance in unskilled work with moderate supervision.
    • Can progress beyond second-grade academic level; may travel alone in familiar places.
  4. Mild Intellectual Disability:
    • Can develop social and communication skills; minimal sensorimotor impairment.
    • Capable of learning academic skills up to about the sixth-grade level by late teens.
  • Achieves adequate social and vocational skills for minimal self-support but may need guidance under stress

Option A: Preschool level: Incorrect. Individuals with mild intellectual disability can learn beyond the preschool level.

Option B: Second-grade level: Incorrect. While some can function at this level, many can progress further.

Option C: Sixth-grade level: Correct. Individuals with mild intellectual disability can learn academic skills up to approximately the sixth-grade level by late teens.

Option D: High school level: Incorrect. Achieving skills at a high school level is typically beyond the capabilities of individuals with mild intellectual disability.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Individuals with mild intellectual disability can learn academic skills up to approximately the sixth-grade level by late teens.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common result of prenatal exposure to opioids?
questions.solution:
INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY CAUSES:

  • Prenatal Health: The mother's physical, psychological, and nutritional health significantly influences fetal brain development. Conditions like diabetes, hypertension, and substance abuse can adversely affect outcomes.
  • Infections: Maternal infections, particularly viral ones like rubella and cytomegalic inclusion disease, can lead to congenital malformations and intellectual disabilities. Timing of the infection during pregnancy is critical.
  • Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS): Caused by alcohol exposure during pregnancy, FAS is a leading preventable cause of intellectual and physical disabilities.
  • Prenatal Drug Exposure: Exposure to substances like opioids can lead to withdrawal symptoms in newborns, while cocaine exposure is linked to low birth weight and behavioural issues.
  • Complications: Maternal malnutrition and conditions like toxemia can lead to prematurity and developmental problems. Premature infants are at higher risk for cognitive impairments.
  • Acquired Childhood Disorders: Infections like encephalitis and meningitis can have lasting effects on cognitive development, while head trauma and asphyxia also pose risks.
  • Environmental Factors: Socioeconomic deprivation, inadequate nurturing, and exposure to toxins can contribute to mild intellectual disabilities and other psychiatric disorders in children.

Option A: Congenital heart defects: These are not typically associated with opioid exposure.

Option B: Withdrawal symptoms in newborns: Infants exposed to opioids can experience withdrawal symptoms shortly after birth, making this the correct choice.

Option C: Hydrocephalus: While it can result from other factors, it is not directly linked to opioid exposure.

Option D: Facial dysmorphism: This is characteristic of fetal alcohol syndrome, not opioid exposure.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Exposure to substances like opioids can lead to withdrawal symptoms in newborns, while cocaine exposure is linked to low birth weight and behavioural issues.

choices.text: Ability to learn new skills quickly
Strong memory for details and facts

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the concept of "theory of mind" in the context of Autism Spectrum Disorder?
questions.solution:
CORE SYMPTOMS OF AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDER (ASD)

  • Persistent Deficits in Social Communication and Interaction:
    • Lack of reciprocal social skills.
    • Minimal or absent social smiles and anticipatory behaviours.
    • Poor eye contact and atypical attachment behaviours.
    • Difficulty understanding social cues and emotions (theory of mind).
    • Awkward and inappropriate social behaviour, leading to social withdrawal.
  • Restricted, Repetitive Patterns of Behaviour, Interests, and Activities:
    • Limited exploratory play and atypical use of toys.
    • Repetitive and ritualistic behaviours(e.g., lining up objects).
    • Resistance to changes in routine, often leading to anxiety or tantrums.
  • Associated Physical Characteristics:
    • Higher rates of minor physical anomalies (e.g., ear malformations).
    • Abnormalities in handedness and dermatoglyphics(fingerprints).
  • Disturbances in Language Development and Usage:
    • Significant difficulties with expressive and receptive language.
    • Use of echolalia and atypical speech patterns.
    • Limited ability to form meaningful sentences.
  • Intellectual Disability:
    • Approximately 30% of children with ASD may be intellectually disabled.
    • Varied IQ scores, with strengths in visuospatial skills.
  • Irritability:
    • Common issues include aggression, self-injurious behaviours, and severe tantrums.
  • Instability of Mood and Affect:
    • Sudden mood changes, often without apparent reason.
  • Response to Sensory Stimuli:
    • Over- or under-responsiveness to sensory inputs (e.g., sounds, pain).
    • Unique sensory preferences, like spinning or humming.
  • Hyperactivity and Inattention:
    • Frequent hyperactivity and short attention spans.
  • Precocious Skills:
    • Some individuals may exhibit splinter skills (e.g., exceptional memory, musical talent).
  • Sleep Problems:
    • High prevalence of insomnia among children with ASD.

Option A: Ability to learn new skills quickly: This is not specifically related to "theory of mind."

Option B: Understanding others' emotions and intentions: Individuals with ASD often struggle with this ability, which affects their social interactions.

Option C: Strong memory for details and facts: While some individuals may have good memory, this is not directly related to theory of mind.

Option D: Proficiency in mathematical reasoning: This skill is unrelated to the concept of understanding social interactions.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Theory of mind refers to the ability to understand and attribute mental states-like intentions and feelings-to oneself and others, which is often impaired in individuals with autism spectrum disorder.

questions.text: Which drug has shown efficacy in reducing aggressive behaviours in children with autism spectrum disorder?
questions.solution:
• Pharmacotherapy for autism spectrum disorder primarily addresses behavioural symptoms rather than core features.
  • Key medications include risperidone and aripiprazole, which help manage irritability and aggression but can cause side effects like weight gain and sedation.
  • Methylphenidate is effective for hyperactivity but may have more side effects in autistic children compared to those with ADHD alone.
  • Atomoxetine is a non-stimulant alternative showing promise. Other medications, like antidepressants and mood stabilizers, have limited efficacy for repetitive behaviours.
  • Continuous monitoring is essential for managing side effects and treatment effectiveness.

Option A: Clonidine: This is used for ADHD and hyperactivity, not specifically for aggressive behaviours.

Option B: Risperidone: Correct. This antipsychotic is effective for managing irritability and aggression in autism.

Option C: Atomoxetine: Primarily for ADHD, not specifically for aggressive behaviours in autism.

Option D: Naltrexone: Lacks significant evidence for efficacy in autism-related aggressive behaviours.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Key medications which has shown efficacy in reducing aggressive behaviours in children with autism spectrum disorder include risperidone and aripiprazole, which help manage irritability and aggression but can cause side effects like weight gain and sedation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a recognized comorbidity with ADHD?
questions.solution:
ADHD

Definition and Characteristics:

  • ADHD (Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder) is a neuropsychiatric condition marked by a persistent pattern of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity.
  • Symptoms can manifest as difficulty sustaining attention, impulsiveness, and hyperactive behaviours.

Biological Basis:

  • Strong evidence supports a biological foundation for ADHD, identified through family history, genetic studies, and neuroimaging.
  • Neurotransmitters, particularly dopamine, are crucial in the manifestation of ADHD symptoms.

Focus on the Brain:

  • The prefrontal cortex is significant due to its heavy reliance on dopamine and connections with other areas involved in attention, decision-making, and impulse control.

Diagnostic Criteria (DSM-5):

  • Age of Onset: Symptoms must be evident by age 12 (previously age 7).
  • Specifiers:
    • Combined presentation
    • Predominantly inattentive presentation
    • Predominantly hyperactive/impulsive presentation
  • Symptoms in Multiple Settings: Impairment must occur in at least two environments (e.g., home, school).
  • Functional Impairment: Symptoms should interfere with social, academic, or occupational functioning.

Symptoms of ADHD:

  • Inattention:
    • Poor attention to detail, difficulty maintaining focus, forgetfulness, and distractibility.
  • Hyperactivity:
    • Fidgeting, inability to remain seated, excessive talking, and difficulty engaging in quiet activities.
  • Impulsivity:
    • Acting without thinking, interrupting others, and difficulty waiting for one's turn.
  • Associated issues: Memory deficits, learning disabilities, and perceptual-motor impairments.

Comorbid Disorders:

  • ADHD is frequently associated with other conditions, including:
    • Learning disorders
    • Anxiety disorders
    • Mood disorders
    • Disruptive behaviour disorders

Option A: Schizophrenia: While it can occur, it is not commonly associated as a primary comorbidity with ADHD.

Option B: Learning disorders: Correct. Many children with ADHD also experience learning disabilities, complicating their educational experience.

Option C: Autism in all cases: This is not true; while ADHD can co-occur with autism, it does not occur in all cases.

Option D: Chronic fatigue syndrome: This is not typically recognized as a comorbidity with ADHD.

questions.text: What is a common concern regarding the long-term use of methylphenidate?
questions.solution:
Treatment:

Pharmacotherapy: First-line treatment for ADHD.

  1. CNS Stimulants: Most effective, generally mild side effects.
  2. Non-stimulants: Atomoxetine and α-agonists are alternatives.

CNS Stimulants:

  • Types:
    • Methylphenidate: Effective in 75% of cases; forms include Concerta (extended-release) and transdermal patches.
    • Amphetamines: Used if methylphenidate is ineffective.

Side Effects:

  • Common: Decreased appetite, insomnia, headaches.
  • Potential growth suppression; "drug holidays" may mitigate this.

Non-stimulant Medications:

Atomoxetine:

  • Norepinephrine uptake inhibitor; black-box warning for suicidal thoughts.
  • Monitored for blood pressure and heart rate.

α-Agonists (Clonidine and Guanfacine):

  • Approved for children 6 years and older.
  • Common side effects: Somnolence, fatigue, hypotension.

Other Medications:

  • Antidepressants: Used with caution; SSRIs not effective for ADHD alone.
  • Bupropion: Sometimes effective but not a first choice.
  • Tricyclic Antidepressants: Generally avoided due to cardiac risks.

Option A: Increased weight gain: Stimulants are more likely to cause decreased appetite, which can lead to weight loss rather than weight gain.

Option B: Growth suppression: Long-term use of methylphenidate has been associated with slight growth suppression, especially if used continuously without drug holidays.

Option C: Development of tics: While some children may experience tics, it is not a universally observed effect, and the concern of growth suppression is more prominent.

Option D: Enhanced cognitive function: While medications can improve attention and focus, they do not directly enhance cognitive function; instead, they help manage ADHD symptoms, enabling better learning.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Long-term use of methylphenidate has been associated with slight growth suppression, especially if used continuously without drug holidays.

questions.text: Which of the following behaviours is most indicative of Conduct Disorder?
questions.solution:
OPPOSITIONAL DEFIANT DISORDER (ODD)

Definition: ODD is characterized by enduring patterns of negativistic, disobedient, and hostile behaviour toward authority figures.

Behavioural Features:

  • Frequent arguments with adults.
  • Easily annoyed and angry.
  • Blames others for mistakes.
  • Deliberately annoys others.
  • Symptoms often present in home settings but may not be evident in other contexts.

Diagnostic Criteria:

  • Duration of symptoms: At least 6 months.
  • DSM-5 categories: Angry/Irritable mood, Argumentative/Defiant behaviour, Vindictiveness.
  • Requires at least four symptoms from these categories.

Consequences: Impairs interpersonal relationships and academic performance; can lead to isolation and low self-esteem.

Etiology: Risk factors include childhood maltreatment, harsh parenting, and exposure to violence in media.

CONDUCT DISORDER

Definition: Conduct Disorder is characterized by a pattern of behaviour that violates the rights of others and societal norms.

Behavioural Features:

  • Aggression toward people and animals.
  • Destruction of property.
  • Theft or deceitfulness.
  • Frequent violations of rules.

Diagnostic Criteria:

  • Requires at least three specific symptoms over 12 months, with at least one symptom in the last 6 months.
  • Symptoms must cause significant impairment in social or academic functioning.

Subtypes:

  • Childhood-onset: Symptoms before age 10.
  • Adolescent-onset: No symptoms before age 10.

Associated Disorders: Often co-occurs with ADHD, depression, and learning disorders.

Option A: Incorrect: Blaming others is more characteristic of ODD.

Option B: Incorrect: While temper outbursts can occur in both disorders, they are more prevalent in ODD.

Option C: Correct: Conduct Disorder is defined by severe, aggressive behaviours, including bullying.

Option D: Incorrect: Defiance is a key feature of ODD, not Conduct Disorder.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Differences between ODD and Conduct Disorder:

  • ODD involves less severe behaviours focussed on defiance and negativity.
  • Conduct Disorder includes more serious antisocial behaviours that violate the rights of others.

Long-term Outcomes: Early disruptive behaviours can lead to chronic issues and potential development of antisocial personality disorder in adulthood.

questions.text: What type of cognitive impairment is described as "temporary confusion" ?
questions.solution:
NEUROCOGNITIVE DISORDERS

  • Delirium: Short-term confusion and changes in cognition.
    • Subcategories:
      1. General medical condition (e.g., infection)
      2. Substance-induced (e.g., drugs like cocaine)
      3. Multiple causes (e.g., head trauma, kidney disease)
      4. Other/multiple etiologies (e.g., sleep deprivation, medications)
    • Option A: Delirium: This is correct; delirium is characterized by acute confusion and changes in cognition, typically short-term.
    • Option B: Dementia: This is a chronic and progressive cognitive decline, not temporary.
    • Option C: Amnestic disorder: This focuses on memory impairment due to other conditions and is not characterized by temporary confusion.
    • Option D: Neurocognitive disorder: This is a broader category that includes chronic conditions, not specifically temporary confusion.

KEY TAKEWAYS: Delirium: Short-term confusion and changes in cognition.

choices.text: Attention is severely impaired in both conditions, with no differences
Attention deficits are typically more pronounced in dementia than in delirium
Delirium presents with poor attention, while dementia typically has intact attention in the early stages
Both conditions exhibit poor attention, but only delirium shows fluctuating attention throughout the day

questions.text: Which of the following best characterizes the attention deficits seen in delirium versus dementia?
questions.solution:
Option A: Attention is severely impaired in both conditions, with no differences.

This statement is incorrect. While attention is impaired in both, the degree and pattern of impairment differ significantly between the two conditions.

Option B: Attention deficits are typically more pronounced in dementia than in delirium.

This statement is incorrect. Delirium typically presents with more severe attention deficits compared to dementia, especially in the acute phase.

Option C: Delirium presents with poor attention, while dementia typically has intact attention in the early stages.

This statement is correct. Delirium is characterized by poor attention, while early-stage dementia may retain better attention, which deteriorates over time.

Option D: Both conditions exhibit poor attention, but only delirium shows fluctuating attention throughout the day.

This statement is partially correct. Delirium does show fluctuating attention, but dementia can also have variability in attention as it progresses.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is best indicated for delirium secondary to alcohol withdrawal?
questions.solution:
PHARMACOLOGIC TREATMENT OF DELIRIUM

  • Typical Antipsychotics
    • Haloperidol:
      • Side Effects: Extrapyramidal side effects, prolonged QTc.
      • Comments: Most commonly used; can also be administered intramuscularly.
    • Atypical Antipsychotics
      • Risperidone:
        • Side Effects: Concerns about extrapyramidal symptoms; limited data in delirium.
      • Olanzapine:
        • Side Effects: Risk of metabolic syndrome; higher mortality in dementia patients.
      • Quetiapine:
        • Side Effects: More sedating.
      • Benzodiazepines
        • Lorazepam:
          • Side Effects: Respiratory depression, paradoxical agitation.
          • Comments: Best for delirium secondary to alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal; may worsen other types of delirium.

Option A: Quetiapine

While quetiapine can help with agitation, it is not the first choice for alcohol withdrawal-related delirium.

Option B: Lorazepam

Lorazepam is the preferred treatment for delirium due to alcohol withdrawal, as it can help manage symptoms and prevent complications.

Option C: Haloperidol

Haloperidol can be used for agitation in delirium but may worsen symptoms if the delirium is alcohol withdrawal-related.

Option D: Olanzapine

Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic that is less commonly used in acute withdrawal settings compared to benzodiazepines.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Lorazepam is the preferred treatment for delirium due to alcohol withdrawal, as it can help manage symptoms and prevent complications.

questions.text: Which of the following neurological conditions is a common cause of delirium?
questions.solution:
DELIRIUM ETIOLOGY

Common Causes of Delirium

  • Central Nervous System Disorders
    • Seizures (postictal, nonconvulsive status)
    • Migraines
    • Head injuries (e.g., tumors, hemorrhages)

Predisposing Factors for Delirium

  • Demographic Characteristics
    • Age: 65 years and older
    • Gender: Male
  • Cognitive Status
    • History of dementia or cognitive impairment
    • Presence of depression
  • Functional Status
    • Dependence, immobility, low activity levels
  • Sensory Impairment
    • Issues with hearing or vision
  • Nutritional Factors
    • Dehydration and malnutrition
  • Drug Factors
    • Use of psychoactive drugs, especially with anticholinergic properties
  • Coexisting Medical Conditions
    • Severe illnesses, chronic diseases, infections, trauma

Option A: Alzheimer's disease primarily contributes to dementia rather than acute delirium.

Option B: The postictal state after a seizure can lead to confusion and altered mental status, making it a common cause of delirium.

Option C: Multiple sclerosis can lead to chronic cognitive issues, not typically acute delirium.

Option D: Parkinson's disease is more associated with long-term cognitive changes rather than acute episodes of delirium.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: The postictal state after a seizure can lead to confusion and altered mental status, making it a common cause of delirium

choices.text: Confusion and ataxia in the evening

questions.text: What is a characteristic of Sundowner Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Sundowner Syndrome is characterized by confusion, drowsiness, and ataxia, particularly in the late afternoon or evening.

A and C are incorrect as they suggest positive changes not associated with the syndrome.

D is incorrect as cognitive function typically does not improve in dementia.

PSYCHIATRIC AND NEUROLOGIC CHANGES IN DEMENTIA:

  • Personality Changes:
    • Preexisting traits may become more pronounced.
    • Patients may become more introverted.
    • Decreased concern for the effects of their behaviour on others.
    • Paranoid delusions can lead to hostility towards family and caregivers.
    • Frontal and temporal lobe involvement may cause irritability and explosive behaviour.
  • Hallucinations and Delusions:
    • 20-30% of patients, especially those with Alzheimer's type dementia, may experience hallucinations.
    • 30-40% may have delusions, often paranoid or persecutory.
    • Physical aggression can occur in patients with psychotic symptoms.
  • Mood Changes:
    • Depression and anxiety are common, affecting 40-50% of patients.
    • Full depressive disorder may be present in 10-20%.
    • Patients may display extremes of emotion, like pathologic laughter or crying.
  • Cognitive Changes:
    • Aphasia, apraxia, and agnosia are prevalent.
    • Neurologic signs may include seizures in some patients.
    • Primitive reflexes and myoclonic jerks can be present.
  • Vascular Dementia Symptoms:
    • May include headaches, dizziness, and focal neurologic signs.
    • Pseudobulbar palsy, dysarthria, and dysphagia are more common.
  • Cognitive Impairments:
    • Reduced ability to generalize and solve problems.
    • Compromised reasoning and judgment abilities.
    • Catastrophic reaction can occur, leading to agitation when aware of deficits.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Sundowner Syndrome:

  • Characterized by confusion, drowsiness, and ataxia, especially in the evening.
  • Symptoms can worsen with sedative use or diminished external stimuli.

choices.text: Core features include significant memory loss as the primary symptom.
Visual hallucinations and fluctuating cognition are hallmark characteristics
This disorder is primarily diagnosed based on the presence of major depression symptoms
Neurocognitive Disorder with Lewy Bodies typically occurs before any motor symptoms appear

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Neurocognitive Disorder with Lewy Bodies is true?
questions.solution:
DEMENTIA CAUSE & DIAGNOSIS:

  • Frontotemporal Neurocognitive Disorder:
    • Variants:
      • Behavioural Variant: Disinhibition, apathy, changes in social behaviour.
      • Language Variant: Affects language skills, word-finding difficulties.
    • Diagnosis:
      • Probable: Evidence of genetic cause and neuroimaging findings.
      • Possible: Some criteria but not all met.
    • Neurocognitive Disorder with Lewy Bodies:
      • Core Features:
        • Fluctuating cognition, attention, alertness.
        • Recurrent visual hallucinations.
        • Parkinsonian symptoms post-cognitive decline.
      • Diagnosis:
        • Probable: At least two core features or one core/one suggestive.
        • Possible: One core feature present.
      • Vascular Neurocognitive Disorder:
        • Characteristics:
          • Cognitive decline after cerebrovascular events.
          • Typically affects complex attention and executive function.
        • Diagnosis:
          • Probable: Neuroimaging evidence of cerebrovascular disease.
          • Possible: No imaging or documented relationship between events and cognitive changes.

Option A:

While memory loss can occur, the core features specifically emphasize fluctuations in cognition, attention, and visual hallucinations rather than memory as the primary symptom.

Option B:

This statement accurately highlights the hallmark characteristics of Neurocognitive Disorder with Lewy Bodies, including fluctuating cognition and recurrent well-formed visual hallucinations.

Option C:

Diagnosis of Neurocognitive Disorder with Lewy Bodies does not primarily rely on depressive symptoms; it is based on cognitive and motor symptoms.

Option D:

In this disorder, Parkinsonian symptoms usually appear after the onset of cognitive decline, not before.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is associated with a risk of hepatotoxicity and is rarely used in treating Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
TREATMENT OF DEMENTIA

Pharmacotherapy

  • Medications:
    • Sedative- hypnotics for insomnia and anxiety.
    • Antidepressants for depression.
    • Antipsychotics for delusions and hallucinations (monitor for adverse effects).
  • Cholinesterase Inhibitors:
    • Donepezil, rivastigmine, galantamine, and tacrine for mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease.
    • Improve memory and cognitive function but do not prevent degeneration.
  • Memantine:
    • Protects neurons from glutamate toxicity; can be combined with donepezil.

Option A: Donepezil is well-tolerated and widely used, with a good safety profile.

Option B: Rivastigmine is commonly used but has been associated with gastrointestinal side effects rather than hepatotoxicity.

Option C: Tacrine is rarely used due to its potential for hepatotoxicity, making it less favourable compared to other cholinesterase inhibitors.

Option D: Galantamine is used for cognitive impairment but does not have the same level of hepatotoxic risk as tacrine.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Tacrine is associated with the risk of hepatotoxicity in patients with Alzheimer disease.

choices.text: Psychosis is more commonly observed during the ictal phase of seizures than interictal
Mood disorders, such as depression, are rarely seen in patients with epilepsy
Increased religiosity and personality changes are often noted in patients with temporal lobe epilepsy
Most patients with epilepsy do not require any psychological support

questions.text: Which statement accurately reflects the psychiatric considerations in patients with epilepsy?
questions.solution:
EPILEPSY

Psychiatric Symptoms:

  • Personality disorders, mood disorders, and psychotic symptoms may be more common in patients with epilepsy, particularly those with temporal lobe epilepsy.

Psychogenic Nonepileptic Seizures (PNES):

  • Not caused by electrical disturbances in the brain.
  • Patients may retain some awareness during episodes, differentiating them from epileptic seizures.

Postictal State:

  • After a generalized tonic-clonic seizure, patients experience gradual recovery of consciousness and may feel confused or fatigued.

Option A: Psychosis is more commonly observed during the ictal phase of seizures than interictal.

False. Psychotic symptoms are generally more prevalent during the interictal period rather than the ictal phase. Ictal symptoms are typically characterized by disorganized behaviour rather than psychosis.

Option B: Mood disorders, such as depression, are rarely seen in patients with epilepsy.

False. Mood disorders, including depression and anxiety, are more common in patients with epilepsy than in the general population. This can significantly affect the patient's quality of life.

Option C: Increased religiosity and personality changes are often noted in patients with temporal lobe epilepsy.

True. Patients with temporal lobe epilepsy frequently exhibit personality changes, including heightened religiosity and emotional changes, as part of their condition.

Option D: Most patients with epilepsy do not require any psychological support.

False. Many patients with epilepsy benefit from psychological support and counselling to address the psychosocial implications of their diagnosis, including coping with chronic illness and managing stigma.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Increased religiosity and personality changes are often noted in patients with temporal lobe epilepsy.

choices.text: Method used in the suicide attempt
Presence of a mental health disorder
Ability of the family to provide adequate supervision and support

questions.text: Which of the following is the MOST important factor to consider when determining the need for psychiatric hospitalization after a suicide attempt?
questions.solution:
While all the factors listed are important, the key consideration is whether the family can adequately monitor and support the child/adolescent after a suicide attempt. Even a low-lethality attempt may warrant hospitalization if the family is unable to ensure the patient's safety.

Screening for Suicidal Thoughts:

  • Suicidal ideation should always be directly asked about during the mental status examination, especially if the patient is depressed.
  • Questions to ask include:
    • "Are you or have you ever been suicidal?"
    • "Do you want to die?"
    • "Do you feel so bad that you might hurt yourself?"

Warning Signs of Suicidal Intent:

  • Eight out of ten individuals who ultimately commit suicide give warnings of their intent.
  • A patient who admits to having a plan for suicide is at high risk.
  • If a previously agitated patient becomes quiet and less verbal about their distress, it can be an ominous sign of impending suicide.

Risk Factors for Suicide:

  • Previous suicide attempts or fantasizing about suicide.
  • Anxiety, depression, and exhaustion.
  • Availability of means to carry out suicide (e.g., firearms, medications).
  • Concern for the effect of suicide on family members (guilt or sense of responsibility).
  • Verbalized suicidal ideation(talking about wanting to die).
  • Preparation of a will or resignation after periods of agitated depression.
  • A proximal life crisis, such as mourning a loss or impending surgery.
  • Family history of suicide increases risk.
  • Pervasive pessimism or hopelessness about the future.

Additional Warning Signs:

  • Suicide notes increase the risk of suicide.
  • Family history of suicide is a significant risk factor.
  • Impulsivity and pervasive pessimism about the future are also strong indicators of increased risk.

Clinical Decision-Making:

  • If a patient is determined to be at imminent risk of suicide, hospitalization or other protective measures are necessary.
  • In cases where the risk is not immediate but the potential for suicide exists as long as the depression remains untreated, close monitoring is essential.

choices.text: A form of failure to thrive due to malnutrition from external factors
A syndrome characterized by growth retardation and abnormal social behaviours due to emotional neglect
A psychological disorder causing excessive appetite and rapid growth
A rare genetic disorder causing excessive shortness of stature

questions.text: What is psychosocial dwarfism in children?
questions.solution:
Psychosocial dwarfism occurs when a child experiences significant growth retardation and abnormal eating behaviours due to emotional neglect, often in a dysfunctional home environment. Once removed from the neglectful environment, the child's growth can normalize.

CHILD ABUSE:

  • Physical and sexual abuse can occur in children of any age, gender, ethnicity, and socioeconomic background.
  • Psychiatric signs commonly associated with abuse include fear, guilt, anxiety, depression, and ambivalence regarding disclosure.
  • Sexually abused children may exhibit precocious sexual behaviour and knowledge beyond their developmental level.
  • Abused children may display sadistic or aggressive behaviours, often mimicking behaviours they've experienced.
  • Physical evidence is often absent in cases of sexual abuse, so careful history-taking is crucial.

CHILD NEGLECT: FAILURE TO THRIVE

Assessment:

  • Neglect occurs when a parent or caretaker fails to provide adequate food, shelter, education, or supervision.
  • Children in neglectful situations may suffer from physical, emotional, or mental impairment.
  • Neglect can lead to Failure to Thrive, a condition where infants (usually under 1 year old) become malnourished without an organic cause.
  • The cause is often a disturbed relationship between the caregiver and child, such as rejection and withdrawal.

Psychosocial Dwarfism:

  • A rare condition in older children, where growth retardation and delayed epiphyseal maturation occur due to disturbed relationships.
  • Children may exhibit bizarre behaviours like eating from garbage, drinking toilet water, and bingeing and vomiting.
  • Growth hormone deficiencies occur in half of these children.
  • Once removed from the neglectful environment, children's growth normalizes, and their endocrine abnormalities resolve.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Psychosocial dwarfism is a rare condition in older children, where growth retardation and delayed epiphyseal maturation occur due to disturbed relationships.

choices.text: Jumping in front of a train

questions.text: In India, which of the following is the most common method used for committing suicide?
questions.solution:
SUICIDE

Definition:

  • Suicide: A deliberate self-inflicted act with the intent to end life, resulting in death.
  • Deliberate Self-Harm (DSH): Any act of intentionally injuring oneself, regardless of the outcome.
  • Suicidal Attempt: A nonfatal act of suicide with the intent to die, but the individual survives.
  • Suicidal Gesture: An act of self-harm with no intent to die, though accidental death may occur.

Common Risk Factors for Suicide

  • Psychiatric Disorders:
    • Depression: Major depression is a key risk factor.
    • Alcoholism & Drug Dependence.
    • Schizophrenia.
    • Genetic Factors: Family history and biochemical factors (e.g., low 5-HIAA levels).
  • Physical Disorders: Chronic, painful, or incurable illnesses (e.g., cancer, AIDS) can lead to suicide.
  • Psychosocial Factors:
    • Life stressors such as marital disputes, family problems, financial difficulties, and the loss of a loved one.
    • Social isolation and significant life changes (e.g., failure, dowry issues, pregnancy).

Common Methods of Suicide

  • Ingestion of Poison: Most common (34.8% in India).
  • Hanging: Second most common (32.2%).
  • Burning: 8.8%.
  • Drowning: 6.7%.
  • Jumping in front of vehicles or trains: 3%.

choices.text: Parenteral antipsychotics should be preferred in most cases

questions.text: Which of the following is TRUE regarding the use of antipsychotic medications in managing excited patients?
questions.solution:
While parenteral antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol) can be used in emergencies, they should be used with caution, especially in treatment-naive patients.

Oral antipsychotics are generally preferred in routine clinical settings.

ECT is not used to manage excitement or violence directly unless there's a clear indication.

Management:

  • Examination:
    • The psychiatrist should approach the patient with empathy but also exude confidence and be firm.
  • Interventions:
    • Reassurance: Often ineffective alone but should be tried first.
    • Sedation:
      • Diazepam (5-10 mg)or lorazepam (1-2 mg) can be given parenterally.
      • In psychotic patients, haloperidol (2-10 mg) can be added with diazepam or promethazine.
      • Care is needed when administering parenteral antipsychotics, especially to treatment-naïve patients. Oral antipsychotics are preferred in routine clinical settings.
    • Restraint:
      • A last resort when needed, done humanely, and preferably with written consent from relatives.
      • Restraint should not be prolonged beyond a few hours and should be removed when no longer necessary.
      • A second opinion from another mental health professional is useful.
    • Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT):
      • Not for managing excitement or violence directly. It should only be used with a clear indication, and it must be documented in the case notes.
